name: Gaz
quote: I’m not trying to be famous — I’m trying to make Monday less powerful

sections.title: ORIGIN
sections.question: What is your earliest memory
sections.answer: Earliest memory? I’m not gonna pretend I remember the actual crawling like it’s some Oscar speech… but I do remember the vibe: the living room carpet rough as a Brillo pad, telly humming, and the adults talking like I wasn’t there. I was a small lad with big eyes and a head full of noise, dragging myself toward anything shiny — remote controls, biscuit tins, the dangerous edge of the coffee table like it owed me money. First steps weren’t heroic… just me wobbling into the world like a pint trying not to spill.

sections.title: YOUNG GAZ
sections.question: What was it like growing up?
sections.answer: Growing up was proper West Mids real: bus fumes, chip fat, corner shops where the bell rings like judgement. I learned early that life is mainly waiting — waiting for the bus, waiting for wages, waiting for your mate to stop chatting nonsense outside the offy. School was half survival, half comedy. I weren’t the toughest, weren’t the cleverest… but I could make a dead corridor feel like a party with one stupid joke and a crisp packet football. That’s where the “Gaz” thing started — people clocked I could turn nothing into something.

sections.title: TRAGEDYS
sections.question: Was there ever any tragic moments that could have affected your stylings?
sections.answer: Tragedy-wise, keep it real: nothing cinematic, just the slow stuff that shapes you. Redundancies, doors closing, family members getting tired in a way you can’t fix with banter. I watched adults get worn down by bills and silence, and that did something to me — made me swear I’d never let the room go flat if I could help it. That’s where the loudness comes from. Not ego. Defence mechanism. If I’m cracking jokes, I’m basically holding the ceiling up.

sections.title: OOPS
sections.question: Did you ever have any bad accidents growing up that shaped you?
sections.answer: Accidents: I had a stupid one — clipped by my own impatience. I was bombing it on a battered bike like I was in a music video, hit a pothole that looked innocent, and I went flying. Nothing dramatic, but enough to learn your body ain’t a rental. I remember lying there laughing, then realising I was laughing so I wouldn’t cry. That’s the Gaz blueprint: fall over, make it funny, get up, keep moving.

sections.title: CHIPPY TIME
sections.question: What was your first romantic experience?
sections.answer: First love was soft, mate. Not a “power ballad” thing — more like a quiet tune under all the noise. I fell for a girl who smelled like shampoo and bus seats (don’t judge, that’s romance round here). We used to share chips and talk about leaving town like it was a sure thing, like we weren’t skint teenagers. She laughed at my daftness but also saw the tired bit underneath. Didn’t last — first loves rarely do — but it taught me that being loud means nothing if you can’t be gentle when it matters.

sections.title: FUTURE
sections.question: How did you form and what were your first gigs like?
sections.answer: Music came in like a crowbar. Me, Baz, and Deano weren’t trying to be a “movement” — we were just trying to make the week feel less like a spreadsheet. The early sessions were cables everywhere, cheap speakers, someone always saying “one more take” like we had infinite time. When it clicks, it’s not fame you feel — it’s relief. Like you found a door in a wall you thought was solid. And that “three step patè” thing you mentioned? Sounds like SoundCloud lads seasoning the stew with chaos — fair play to ‘em, but we’re more grit and gravy than bouncy meat science.
